question.text: The value of \(x\) which satisfies the equation \(\log _{2}\left(x^{2}-3\right)-\log _{2}(6 x-10)+1=0\)

solution.text:
\(x^{2}-3>0,6 x-10>0 \Rightarrow x>\sqrt{3}\)
\(\begin{array}{l}
\text {Also } \log _{2}\left(\frac{x^{2}-3}{6 x-10}\right)=-1 \Rightarrow \frac{x^{2}-3}{6 x-10}=\frac{1}{2} \\
\Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-3=3 x-5 \\
\Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-3 x+2=0 \Rightarrow x=1,2 \\
\text {Thus, } \quad x=2
\end{array}\)

question.text: Solve <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mfenced><mn>6</mn></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mfenced><mn>5</mn></mfenced></math>.

solution.text:
The given expression is 
log102x+1+x=log106+xlog105

We know that logmx+logmy=logmxy & logmx+logmy=logmxy

⇒log102x+1=xlog105-log1010+log106

⇒log102x+1=-log102x+log106

⇒log102x+1+log102x=log106

⇒log102x2x+1=log106

Taking antilog on both sides, we get

⇒2x2x+1=6

⇒2x2+2x-6=0

⇒2x-22x+3=0

⇒2x=2⇒x=1                                            Hence, x=1

question.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>log</mi><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></msub><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> belongs to the set

solution.text:
As we know that logab>0, if 0<a<1&0<b<1.

Given, log13x2+2x>0

⇒0<x2+2x<1

Breaking into two cases:

Case I : x2+2x>0

⇒xx+2>0

⇒x∈-∞,-2∪0,∞     ...1

Case II : x2+2x<1

⇒x2+2x-1<0

⇒x+1+2x+1-2<0

⇒-1-2<x<-1+2    ...2

From equation 1 and 2,we get

x∈-1-2,-2∪0,2-1

Thus, -1-2,-2∪0,2-1 is correct option.

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>175</mn></msub><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>343</mn></msub><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo></math> then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>42</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mfenced></math> is equal to

solution.text:
log1755x=log3437x=k

⇒57=175343k⇒k=12⇒x=7.

question.text: Sum of all possible values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> which satisfy the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>9</mn></msub><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math> is:

solution.text:
We have,

log3(x-3)=log9(x-1)

⇒logx-3log3=logx-1log9

⇒logx-3log3=logx-1log32

⇒logx-3log3=logx-12log3

⇒2logx-3=logx-1

⇒logx-32=logx-1

⇒(x-3)2=x-1

⇒ x2-7x+10=0

⇒x=2, 5

x=2 is not possible as log3(x-3) is not defined for x=2.

Therefore, x=5.

question.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="|" close="|"><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mn>5</mn><msqrt><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mn>3</mn></msqrt></msup></mtd><mtd><msup><mn>5</mn><msqrt><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mn>3</mn></msqrt></msup></mtd><mtd><msup><mn>5</mn><msqrt><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mn>3</mn></msqrt></msup></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mn>3</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup></mtd><mtd><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>1</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>01</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup></mtd><mtd><msup><mn>7</mn><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mfenced></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Let

D=5log535log535log533-log1/3(4)(0.1)log0.01(4)7log7(3)735

C2↔C2-C1 and C3↔C3-C1

⇒D=5log535log53-5log535log53-5log533-log1/3(4)(0.1)log0.01(4)-3-log1/3(4)7log7(3)-3-log1/3(4)7-4-2

⇒D=5log53003-log1/3(4)(0.1)log0.01(4)-3-log1/3(4)7log7(3)-3-log1/3(4)7-4-2

⇒D=5log53003-log1/3(4)4log0.010.1-4-log1/333log77-4-log1/337-4-2

∵clogab=blogac

⇒D=5log53003-log1/3(4)412-4131-417-4-2

∵logab=1logba

⇒D5log53004-2-17-4-2=0

question.text: The set of all solutions of the equation \(\log _{3} x \log _{4} x \log _{5} x=\log _{3} x \log _{4} x+\log _{4} x \log _{5} x\) \(+\log _{5} x \log _{3} x\) is

solution.text:
For \(x=1\), both parts of the equation vanish, consequently \(x=1\) is root of the equation. For \(x \neq 1\)
\(\begin{aligned}
1 &=\frac{1}{\log _{5} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{3} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{4} x}=\log _{x} 5+\log _{x} 3+\log _{x} 4 \\
&=\log _{x} 60
\end{aligned}\)
\(\Rightarrow x=60\). Thus the required set is \(\{1,60\}\).

question.text: If \(n>1\), the value of \(\frac{1}{\log _{2} n}+\frac{1}{\log _{3} n}+\ldots+\frac{1}{\log _{53} n}\) is
The solution of the equation \(4^{\log _{2} \log x}=\log x-(\log x)^{2}+1\) is

solution.text:
\(\log _{2} \log x\) is meaningful if \(x>1\)
Since \(4^{\log _{2} \log x}=2^{2 \log _{2} \log x}=\left(2^{\log _{2} \log x}\right)^{2}=(\log x)^{2}\)
\(\left[a^{\log _{a} x}=x, a>0, a \neq 1\right]\)
So the given equation reduces to
\(\begin{array}{ll} 
2(\log x)^{2}-\log x-1=0 \\
\Rightarrow \log x=1, \log x=-1 / 2 . \text { But for } x>1 \\
\log x>0 \text { so } \log x=1 \text { i.e. } x=e
\end{array}\)

question.text: Suppose <math><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi>y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi>z</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math> and distinct and <math><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi> </mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi> </mi><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi> </mi><mi>z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo></math> if the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>z</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>·</mo><mi> </mi><msup><mi>y</mi><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>z</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>·</mo><mi> </mi><msup><mi>z</mi><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msup><mi> </mi></math> is <math><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup></math> , then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo></math>

solution.text:
Let X=x1lny+1lnz.y1lnz+1lnx . z1lnx+1lny

⇒     ln x=ln x1lny+1ln z +ln y 1ln z +1ln x+1ln x +1ln y ln z

Now given ln x+ ln y+ln z=0

∴    ln xln y+ln zln y=-1

Similarly ln yln x+ln zln x=-1 and

ln xln z+ln yln z=-1

∴    R.H.S. =-3

∴   ln X=-3

X=e-3

question.text: The solution set of \(\log _{|\sin x|}\left(x^{2}-8 x+23\right)\) \(>\frac{3}{\log _{2}|\sin x|}\) contains

solution.text:
\(x \in (2 n+1) \pi / 2, n \pi\) where \(n \in \mathbf{I}\). The given inequality can be written as \(\frac{\log _{2}\left(x^{2}-8 x+23\right)}{\log _{2}|\sin x|} > \frac{3}{\log _{2}|\sin x|}\)
As \(\log _{2}|\sin x| < 0\), we get
\(\begin{aligned}& \log _{2}\left(x^{2}-8 x+23\right) < 3 \\\Rightarrow & x^{2}-8 x+23 < 2^{3}=8 \\\Rightarrow & x^{2}-8 x+15 < 0 \\\Rightarrow & (x-5)(x-3) < 0 \Rightarrow 3 < x < 5\end{aligned}\)
For \(x \in(3,5), x \in \pi, \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2} .\) Hence
\(x \in(3, \pi) \cup\left(\pi, \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right) \cup\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}, 5\right)\)

question.text: The set of all \(x\) satisfying the equation \(x^{\log _{3} x^{2}+\left(\log _{3} x\right)^{2}-10}=1 / x^{2}\) is

solution.text:
Taking log of both the sides with base 3, we have
\(\left(\log _{3} x^{2}+\left(\log _{3} x\right)^{2}-10\right)\left(\log _{3} x\right)=-2 \log _{3} x\)
This equation is equivalent to
\(\log _{3} x=0 \text { or } 2 \log _{3} x+\left(\log _{3} x\right)^{2}-8=0\)
\(\Rightarrow \quad x=1, \log _{3} x=-1 \pm 3\) i.e. \(\log _{3} x=2, \log _{3} x=-4\)
Hence \(x=1,3^{2}, 3^{-4}=1,9,1 / 81\)

question.text:
Consider the value of $x$ which satisfies the following relation:
$\frac{6}{5} a^{\log _{11} x \cdot \log _{10} a \cdot \log _{10} 5}=3^{\log _{10} \frac{x}{10}}+9^{\log _{100} x+\log _{4} 2}$
This value of $x$ lies between:

solution.text:
We use the fact that $\log _{b} a=\frac{\log _{c} a}{\log _{c} b}$ to simply both the sides.
$\frac{6}{5} a^{\frac{\log x}{\log a} \cdot \frac{\log a}{\log 10} \cdot \frac{\log 5}{\log a}}=3^{\log _{10} x-1}+9^{\frac{1}{\log _{10} x+\frac{1}{2}}}$ ...(1)
Consider the term on the left side:
$a^{\frac{\log x}{\log a} \cdot \frac{\log 5}{\log _{10} 0}}=a^{\log _{u} x \cdot \log _{10} 5}=x^{\log _{10} 5}=5^{\log _{10} x} \quad \text { (how?) }$
Using this in (1), along with the substitution $\log _{10} x=t$, we have
$\begin{aligned}
&\frac{6}{5} 5^{t}=3^{t-1}+9^{\frac{t+1}{2}}=3^{t-1}+3^{t+1}=3^{t}\left(3+\frac{1}{3}\right)=10.3^{t-1} \\
&\Rightarrow 5^{t-2}=3^{t-2} \Rightarrow t=2 \Rightarrow x=100
\end{aligned}$
Thus, the correct option is (D).

question.text:
Solution set of the inequality
\(\log _{x}\left(2 x^{2}+x-1\right)>\log _{x}(2)-1\) 
is

solution.text:
For (1) to hold, we must have
\(\begin{array}{ll}
x  > 0, x \neq 1 \text { and } 2 x^{2}+x-1 > 0 \\
\Rightarrow x > 0, x \neq 1 \text { and }(2 x-1)(x+1) > 0 \\
\Rightarrow x > 1 / 2, x \neq 1
\end{array}\)
We can write (1) as
\(\log _{x}\left(\frac{2 x^{2}+x-1}{2}\right) > -1\)    (2)
For \(1 / 2 < x < 1,(2)\) can be written as
\(\frac{2 x^{2}+x-1}{2} < \frac{1}{x}\)
\(\begin{array}{l}
\Rightarrow \quad 2 x^{3}+x^{2}-x < 2 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 2\left(x^{3}-1\right)+x(x-1) < 0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad(x-1)\left(2 x^{2}+3 x+2\right) < 0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad x < 1 \quad\left[\because 2 x^{2}+3 x+2 > 0 \forall x > 0\right]
\end{array}\)
For \(x > 1,(2)\) can be written as
\(\begin{aligned}
& \frac{2 x^{2}+x-1}{2} > \frac{1}{x} \\
\Rightarrow \quad &(x-1)\left(2 x^{2}+3 x+2\right) > 0
\end{aligned}\)
This is true for each \(x > 1\).
Thus, (1) holds for \(1 / 2 < x < 1, x > 1\).

question.text: Consider the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>log</mi><mrow><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></math> If the sum of the roots is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mi>p</mi><mi>π</mi></mrow><mi>q</mi></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo></math> then evaluate <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>p</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>q</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>

solution.text:
log2sinx(1+cosx)=2
2sinx≠1,  2sinx>0,  1+cosx>0
⇔sinx≠12,sinx>0 and
x≠ odd multiple of π ⇒x∈(0,π)-π4,3π4 (feasible region)
(i) ⇔(2sinx)2=1+cosx
⇔2sin2x=1+cosx
⇔2cos2x+cosx-1=0
⇔(2cosx-1)(cosx+1)=0
⇒cosx=12  …[cosx+1>0]
⇒x=π3
⇒p=1,q=3
⇒p2+q2=10

We have, \(\frac{(x-2)^{10000}(x+1)^{253}\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{971}(x+8)^{4}}{x^{500}(x-3)^{75}(x+2)^{93}} \geq 0\) The critical points are \((-8) \cdot(-2),(-1), 0, \frac{1}{2}, 2,3\) \([\because x \neq-2,0,3]\)
Hence, \(x \in(-\infty,-8] \cup[-8,-2) \cup[-1,0) \cup\left(0, \frac{1}{2}\right] \cup(3, \infty)\) or \(x \in(-\infty,-2) \cup[-1,0) \cup\left(0, \frac{1}{2}\right] \cup(3, \infty)\)
{2} also satisfy the given inequality. Hence, answer is option 4.

question.text: Let \(f(x)=\frac{(x-3)(x+2)(x+6)}{(x+1)(x-5)}\) Find where \(f(x)\) is negative.

solution.text:
We have, \(f(x)=\frac{(x-3)(x+2)(x+6)}{(x+1)(x-5)}\) The critical points are \((-6),(-2),(-1), 3,5\)
For \(f(x)>0, \forall x \in(-6,-2) \cup(-1,3) \cup(5, \infty)\) For \(f(x)<0, \forall x \in(-\infty,-6) \cup(-2,-1) \cup(3,5)\)

question.text: Solve the equation \(\left|\frac{x^{2}-8 x+12}{x^{2}-10 x+21}\right|=-\frac{x^{2}-8 x+12}{x^{2}-10 x+21}\)

solution.text:
This equation has the form \(|f(x)|=-f(x)\) when, \(f(x)=\frac{x^{2}-8 x+12}{x^{2}-10 x+21}\) such an equation is equivalent to the collection of systems \(\left\{\begin{array}{l} f(x)=-f(x), \text { if } f(x) \geq 0 \\ f(x)=f(x), \text { if } f(x)<0 \end{array}\right.\) The first system is equivalent to \(f(x)=0\) and the second system is equivalent to \(f(x)<0\) the combining both systems, we get \(\begin{aligned} f(x) \leq 0 \\ \therefore \frac{x^{2}-8 x+12}{x^{2}-10 x+21} & \leq 0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{(x-2)(x-6)}{(x-3)(x-7)} & \leq 0 \end{aligned}\)
Hence, by Wavy curve method, \(x \in[2,3) \cup[6,7)\)

question.text: Solve the inequality \((x+3)(3 x-2)^{5}(7-x)^{3}(5 x+8)^{2} \geq 0\)

solution.text:
We have, \((x+3)(3 x-2)^{5}(7-x)^{3}(5 x+8)^{2} \geq 0\) \(\begin{array}{ll} \Rightarrow \quad -(x+3)(3 x-2)^{5}(x-7)^{3}(5 x+8)^{2} \geq 0 \\ \Rightarrow (x+3)(3 x-2)^{5}(x-7)^{3}(5 x+8)^{2} \leq 0 \end{array}\) [take before \(x,+\) ve sign in all brackets]
The critical points are \((-3),\left(-\frac{8}{5}\right), \frac{2}{3}, 7\) Hence, \(x \in(-\infty,-3] \cup\left[\frac{2}{3}, 7\right] \cup\left\{-\frac{8}{5}\right\}\)

question.text: Find the number of integral values of <math><mi>x</mi></math> satisfying the inequation: <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi> </mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> .

solution.text:
xxx+2≤1

xx-x-2x+2≤0

Case I x∈0, ∞

x2-x-2x+2≤0

⇒   x-2 x+1x+2 ≤0

⇒  x≤2

⇒   integral values 0, 1, 2

Case II x∈-∞, 0

-x2-x-2x+2≤0

⇒   x>-2

⇒  x=-1

So 4 integral values

question.text: Solve the inequation \(\sqrt{\left(-x^{2}+4 x-3\right)}>6-2 x\)
Let [a] denotes the larger integer not exceeding the real number \(a\). If \(x\) and \(y\) satisfy the equations \(y=2[x]+3\) and \(y=3[x-2]\) simulaneously, determine \([x+y]\)

solution.text:
We have, \(y=2[x]+3=3[x-2]\) \(\ldots(\mathrm{i})\)
\(\begin{array}{ll}\Rightarrow & 2[x]+3=3([x]-2) \quad \text { [from property (i)] } \\ \Rightarrow & 2[x]+3=3[x]-6 \\ \Rightarrow & \quad[x]=9\end{array}\)
From Eq. (i), \(y=2 \times 9+3=21\)
\(\therefore \quad[x+y]=[x+21]=[x]+21=9+21=30\)
Hence, the value of \([x+y]\) is 30

question.text: If \(\{x\}\) and \([x]\) represent fractional and integral part of \(x\) respectively, find the value of \([x]+\sum_{r=1}^{2000} \frac{\{x+r\}}{2000}\)
Solve the equation \(|x-| 4-x||-2 x=4\)

solution.text:
This equation is equivalent to the collection of systems
\(\begin{array}{l}
\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
|x-(4-x)|-2 x=4, \text { if } 4-x \geq 0 \\
|x+(4-x)|-2 x=4, \text { if } 4-x<0
\end{array}\right. \\
\Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
|2 x-4|-2 x=4, & \text { if } x \leq 4 \\
4-2 x=4, & \text { if } x>4
\end{array}\right.  \quad \quad \text{...(i)}
\end{array}\)
The second system of this collection
gives \(x=0\)
but \(x>4\)
Hence, second system has no solution.
The first system of collection Eq. (i) is equivalent to the system of collection
\(\begin{array}{l}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
2 x-4-2 x=4, \text { if } 2 x \geq 4 \\
-2 x+4-2 x=4, \text { if } 2 x<4
\end{array}\right. \\
\Rightarrow \quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-4=4, \text { if } x \geq 2 \\
-4 x=0, \text { if } x<2
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}\)
The first system is failed and second system gives \(x=0\). 
Hence, \(x=0\) is unique solution of the given equation.

question.text: The number of solution(s) the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> is

solution.text:
As the minimum value of x-1+x-2+x-3+x-4 is 4.

Hence number of solutions =0

question.text: Find the set of all \(x\) for which \(\frac{2 x}{\left(2 x^{2}+5 x+2\right)}>\frac{1}{(x+1)}\)

solution.text:
We have, \(\frac{2 x}{\left(2 x^{2}+5 x+2\right)}>\frac{1}{(x+1)}\) \(\Rightarrow \quad \frac{2 x}{(x+2)(2 x+1)}-\frac{1}{(x+1)}>0\) \(\Rightarrow \quad \frac{\left(2 x^{2}+2 x\right)-\left(2 x^{2}+5 x+2\right)}{(x+2)(x+1)(2 x+1)}>0\) \(\Rightarrow \quad-\frac{(3 x+2)}{(x+2)(x+1)(2 x+1)}>0\) or \(\quad \frac{(3 x+2)}{(x+2)(x+1)(2 x+1)}<0\) The critical points are \((-2),(-1),\left(-\frac{2}{3}\right)\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)\)
Hence, \(x \in(-2,-1) \cup\left(-\frac{2}{3},-\frac{1}{2}\right)\)

question.text: Number of integral values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> satisfying the inequation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mfenced><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfenced><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow><mfenced><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced><msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>≤</mo><mn>0</mn></math> are

solution.text:
x2-2x+8ex+2x-3x-8log2x2+3x-52≤0

x2-2x+8,ex+2 and log2x2+3 are positive quantities

Next we have to find condition for x-3,x-5 and x-8

At x=5, the denominator =0. So x=5 is not a solution. Therefore, number of integral solutions will be between 3 and 8 excluding 5 (using wavy curve method)

Thus, we have 5 integral values possible.

question.text: Solution set of equation \(\left|1-\log _{\frac{1}{6}} x\right|+\left|\log _{2} x\right|+2=\left|3-\log _{\frac{1}{6}} x+\log _{\frac{1}{2}} x\right|\) is \(\left[\frac{a}{b}, a\right], a, b \in N\), then the value of \(\frac{(a+b)}{2}\) is

solution.text:
If \(|a+b+c|=|a|+|b|+|c|\) then \(a, b, c\) have same sign
\(\left|1-\log _{1 / 6} x\right|+\left|-\log _{2} x\right|+|2|=| 3-\log _{1/6} x-\log _{2}x|\)
\(\therefore 1-\log _{1 / 6} x \geqslant 0\)
\(\frac{1}{6} \leqslant x\)
\(-\log _{2} x \geqslant 0\)
\(x \leqslant 2\)
\(\therefore x \in\left[\frac{1}{6}, 2\right], a=2\) and \(b=12\)
\(\frac{a+b}{2}=7\)

question.text: Solve the inequation \(\left|1-\frac{|x|}{1+|x|}\right| \geq \frac{1}{2}\).

solution.text:
The given inequation is equivalent to the collection of systems \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}\left|1-\frac{x}{1+x}\right| \geq \frac{1}{2}, \text { if } x \geq 0 \\ \left|1+\frac{x}{1-x} \right| \geq \frac{1}{2}, \text { if } x<0\end{array} \Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{1}{|1+x|} \geq \frac{1}{2}, \text { if } x \geq 0 \\ \frac{1}{|1-x|} \geq \frac{1}{2}, \text { if } x<0\end{array}\right.\right.\) \(\Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{1}{1+x} \geq \frac{1}{2}, \text { if } x \geq 0 \\ \frac{1}{1-x} \geq \frac{1}{2}, \text { if } x<0\end{array} \Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{1-x}{1+x} \geq 0, \text { if } x \geq 0 \\ \frac{1+x}{1-x} \geq 0, \text { if } x<0\end{array}\right.\right.\) \(\Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{x-1}{x+1} \leq 0, \text { if } x \geq 0 \\ \frac{x+1}{x-1} \leq 0, \text { if } x<0\end{array}\right.\) For \(\quad \frac{x-1}{x+1} \leq 0\), if \(x \geq 0\)
\(\begin{array}{ll}\therefore & 0 \leq x \leq 1 \quad \text{...(i)}\\ \text { For } & \frac{x+1}{x-1} \leq 0, \text { if } x<0\end{array}\)
\(\therefore \quad-1 \leq x<0\) ...(ii) Hence, from Eqs. (i) and (ii), the solution of the given equation is \(x \in[-1,1]\) Aliter \(\begin{array}{ll} \left|1-\frac{|x|}{1+|x|}\right| \geq \frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow\left|\frac{1}{1+|x|}\right| \geq \frac{1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{1+|x|} \geq \frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow 1+|x| \leq 2 \text { or }|x| \leq 1 \\ \therefore \quad-1 \leq x \leq 1 \text { or } x \Rightarrow[-1,1] \end{array}\)

question.text: Find the number of solution of the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>-</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi> </mi><mo>+</mo><mi> </mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi> </mi><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math> where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mo>·</mo></mfenced></math> represent the greatest integer function.

solution.text:
2x-x+1=2x    ...1

-x+1=2x, 0≤2x<1,

- x+1=0, x+1=0 

-1≤x<0, -2 ≤2x<0

2x= -2, -1

from equation 1

2x-0=2x, 2x=-2, -1

x=-1, -12
